St. Thomas, 11th Decr. חנוכה 5624/1863.

My dear Mr. Leeser.

Your two welcome letters I have not had any time to answer until today, and even now I have so much to do with Synagogue and school (very small at present,) that I will not be able to afford you all the information you may want respecting my course since I have been hear. But first let me ask why you address me, one of your oldest friends and correspondents by the title of Dr. Sir? Is it a proof of your altered feelings towards me, or an idea that mine could possibly change, or have changed towards you? “Reform is altogether.” I must also premise that your note of Oct. 2nd. found me on a sick bed, and which incapacitated me from public duty for nearly 3 weeks. It was a severe attack of influenza, arising from the sudden change of very hot weather to heavy rains and strong north winds.

I left Kingston on the 9th. Septr., and arrived here בשלום on ער"ה about 7 in the morning too late for סליחות. A large concourse of my members met me at the wharf, and accompanied me to the lodgings they had provided and furnished, until I could purchase my own things. After drinking a glass of wine, we went to Synagogue, for me to say גומל. On returning home, a letter from some of my lady friends was handed me, together with a handsome suit of canonicals, of which they requested my acceptance. In the evening, the congregation being assembled for ערבית, I was led in by the Presidt. & Vice, seated in the President's chair, while the congregation sang ברוך הבא. After which the President from the Tebah addressed me, and on concluding, he and the vice led me to the Tebah, where I addressed the congregation for 10 minutes or so. After which I read the Evening Service, paid musaph? next day, and preached; Mr. Maduro my assistant Reader read the second Evening and following day. I read שבת שיבה and preached on Kippoor my portion was מוסף & כל נדרי, ערבית, a sermon, and נעילה. I did not again preach till Succot, the 1st day. We had a large assembly on הושענה רבה, save on שמיני עצרת, very bad weather, and a thin attendance on שמחת התורה; on which day I had to go to Government House to pay my respects to the Governor, and show my loyalty, it being the late Kings' birthday. Since then I have spoken to the people every sabbath, also on the 25th. Oct., the annual thanksgiving day after the expiration of the hurricane season, on which occasion I sent them all home with red eyes and noses. Except the two Sabbaths when I was too ill to leave the house I have spoken the word. The old members declare that I am much improved, whilst the young ones who only remember me as children are highly pleased with me. On last Monday night the 7th. ?. we had a special service, as the advertisement in the paper stated, as a tribute of loyalty, affection, and homage to the memory of the late Sovereign Frederick VII. The Synagogue was very tastefully hung in black; the four large pillars having black draperies folded around them spirally, the two pilasters at the Hechal, the Tebah, large candlesticks, and brass knobs being covered with table trappings. An audience filling every inch of the building (at least 500 persons) consisting of our congregation, and a very large number of Christians, assembled at 7 PM. The Governor and his suite, and several heads of departments were present; among the rest, the Presbyterian, Lutheran, and Moravian clergymen. The service began with the chanting of the 49th Psalm, then

ערבית; after which ויהי נועם was sung, and the חנוכה lights lighted, and ארוחים ק"ה said, Kaddish & Barecha? sung, and עלינו לשבח read with great Emphasis. I then preached from Ecclesiastes v. 8 ויתרון ארץ בכל היא about an hour. After which, the whole audience standing, I recited, in English, the השכבה for the repose of the kings seal; which set all the Danes crying, men and women. Then followed the הנותן תשועה in English, for which the ark was opened by our old friend Mayer Wolff, who, as it was a public occasion, was dressed in full military uniform, and looked every inch a fine veteran soldier. The whole was concluded with Yigdals, and the יברכך in Hebrew & English, with which we finish all services in the Synagogue. The whole went off with the greatest ?, and will do us good here. I felt highly proud of my congregation, for tho' they always behave well in Synagogue, and are not excelled by any Jewish Assembly for prayer in the known world in this respect, yet on this occasion the whole proceedings were so very orderly and dignified, that they could not have been better. The chaunting and responses were particularly fine. As to my sermon it was much applauded by some, and slightly found fault with ? others, according as they Supposed to be Danes or and Germans. The Holstein question you may suppose is discussed and debated here, and sometimes with great bitterness. Being no partizan, I only spoke of the king as his acts, in giving a most liberal constitution, in endeavoring to unite his people, gaining their love and affection, and counselling his relative, the king of the Greeks, to do the same fully warranted my doing. Judging him by his public acts, he was in truth a patriotic king, and I took advantage of pointing out by the lights of Hanukah, how Israel valued patriotism, which after 2000 years they still continued to celebrate, and how highly they esteemed it in others, especially in those who, with power, combined the desire of granting the rights of civil and religious liberty to their fullest extent, as was the case with the late King. My bold sentiments have made me (for the ?) very popular; and my members are consequently pleased that their minister should be well spoken of, and his preaching admired. But I am too old to be vain of Popular applause: yet I am gratified that the attempt to do my duty has not been exceeded by any other Clergyman in the place.

With reference to the state of parties in the congregation, affairs are much more quietly and peaceably conducted than when they were when I was minister here before. There are a great many young people married and un-married who both think and act far differently to what was then the mode. They keep down the turbulent determinedly; for still some of the old l? remains, constantly kept in a state of fermentation by one of the most mischievous men I ever met with. Some of these dissatisfied ones wanted no minister at all, because their ? would have been made larger to support him. With the exception of a very very few, whom I hope by discretion and prudence to gain over, the ? the whole body of members is well affected to me. We seldom have less than 150 to 180 persons present every Sabbath morning about 20 to 25 every Friday Evening, the same member to mincha? on Sabbath, and about 35 or Sabbath Evening. You will agree with me that this is not bad. I should say that our member, all told, approaches close to 400.

Our funerals and marriages are conducted with great solemnity. I have had 2 of the former, and one of the latter (celebrated in Synagogue) since my arrival. I spoke on Each occasion. The marriage was a s?gated one. The parties (both Israelites) had already been married civilly in New Grenada, and so it was somewhat anomalous. We anticipated some loud complaints when the new assessmt. should be fixed, as the tapes would be so much heavier, but with the exception of the גרום I before mentioned, who threatened to create a scandal, if his assessment was not fixed at the sum he named, there has not been a murmur. The Representatives refused to be frightened; and so he is left to create what scandal he pleases. But he is so much disliked, and Government is so rejoiced at the peaceable turn things have taken under the new minister, that he will, no doubt, take care of what he does, particularly as he is an arrant coward. At this moment, the feeling upper-most among the Jewish public is the enlargement of the Synagogue, very much needed. For this purpose it is proposed to appropriate the present “reserve fund,” amounting to about $3000, and make up the deficiency in the required sum by subscriptions among Jews and Christians. Our old friend Mayer Wolff is very enthusiastic on the subject, so are Dr. Pretto, Messrs. Osorio, Debatte, F?, Cardozo, De Solla, Lusia, Alexr. Levy, Myer, Piza and many others. I will keep you posted in the matter as it progresses.

The Sunday School will, I hope, very soon be reorganized on its old popular footing, and the ceremony of confirmation be again introduced agreeably to Law. There is a good deal of true religious fervor among the majority, and a total indifference to religion, its decencies, and obligations among a few families. But with time the latter may come round. There is work enough cut out for me, but, with God's blessing, I hope to get through it.

There has been some demand for your prayer books (Sephardim) Pentatuech, and small English Bibles. You can send 25 of the latter, and a few of each of the former, by the very first opportunity. Sabbath is so very near that I cannot venture to write more, and as I was assured that my news would be more welcome than any observations I might make on the strange conduct of one of your former friends, about which you last wrote me, I delay making any remarks on your letters till I next take up my pen. Mrs. Nathan has not yet joined me, but she was still in the same unhappy condition as when I left. About Miss Aguilar's reprinted works, I have been forestalled by the person you originally appointed here, but I dare say you will get a good subscription list. I will however do my best.

May God bless and protect you and keep you in health and happiness for many years prays Your friend המוכן תמיד לשרתך

MNNathan
